description.value: This code system contains codes for documenting the various attributes of a Digital Certificate

definition.value: a certificate for a device such as a server or router, used to authenticate the device and establish secure communications between the device and a client.
This type of certificate is used to verify the identity of a device.
a certificate for a collection of individual subscribers acting in a shared capacity, such as an organization.
A certificate for a single person.
a certificate for a specific role on behalf of which a subscriber is authorized to act, such as a Chief Information Officer.

A certificate issued for the purpose of digitally signing information to confirm the author and guarantee that the content has not been altered or corrupted since it was signed by use of a cryptographic hash.
A certificate containing a public key that can encrypt or decrypt electronic messages, files, documents, or data transmissions, or establish or exchange a session key for these same purposes.
A certificate which can be used to obtain assurance of the accuracy of the claimed identity of an entity.

A standard published by the International Telecommunication Union’s Telecommunication Standardization Sector (ITU-T) that defines a framework for public-key certificates, including specification of data objects used to represent the certificates themselves.

DirectTrust is a non-profit health care industry alliance that has established and maintains rules, standards, and policies associated with the operation of the security and trust-in-identity layer for Direct exchange.
The digital certificate is used within the FCBA trust framework.

The SAFE-BioPharma Association develops and maintains policies and practices used by identity credential issuers. SAFE-BioPharma examines and certifies that the identity proofing, credential issuance, and credential management policies and practices of electronic identity credential issuers are comparable to Federal Identity, Credential, and Access Management (FICAM) requirements.

The TEF outlines a common set of principles for trusted exchange and minimum terms and conditions for trusted exchange to bridge the gap between providers’ and patients’ information systems and enable interoperability across disparate health information networks (HINs).
The digital certificate is used within the FICAM trust framework.

Blue Button for Consumers (NBB4C) Trust Bundle – The NBB4C Trust Bundle contains trust anchors of consumer-facing applications (CFAs) that utilize Direct to securely move data from one application to another. Participation in the NBB4C Trust Bundle facilitates secure exchange of health information from provider-controlled applications to consumer-controlled applications such as personal health records (PHRs) using Direct secure messaging protocols.
A trust framework other than DirectTrust, FPKI/Federal Trust Framework, SAFE-BioPharma, NATE Blue Button for Consumers Trust Bundle, or ONC Trusted Exchange Framework.
